warn.NO_DATA: We are sorry, but we do not have enougth data for

tips.norm_data: For objectivity consider normalized data i.e. the number of crashes per 10 000 cars sold
tips.age_mileage: Compare defects by age or mileage

defect.rating: Rating: how serious is the defect?

about.text:
If you have ever chosen a car for yourself, you have probably watched a lot of car reviews, where bloggers of different competence told you about the pros and cons of every car and recommended what to buy. The problem is that all of these reviews are subjective, and if you are a rational mature person, and reliability of a car in the long term is important for you, you may be interested in analysis of call statistics service.

There are awesome sites such as carcomplaints.com, carproblemzoo.com, nhtsa.gov, where people describe problems encountered during the period of their car exploitation. But unfortunately there are no charts on these sites, so you can't visually compare different models and figure out which is more problematic.

that's why I’ve created my own website car-defects.com, collecting all the information from these useful resources and presenting it as graphs. Here you can compare car models, model generations and versions, visualize by age or mileage, and, for objectivity, consider normalized data i.e. the number of crashes per 10,000 cars sold. The site has information about 4 million crashes, and you can also contribute to the project by sharing your own experience.

It's a non-commercial project, created on a voluntary basis, and it is still on alpha release.

japanese_top_selling_compact_suvs.title: Japanese top-selling compact SUVs
japanese_top_selling_compact_suvs.text:
Were you aware, that in Japanese top-selling compact SUVs - Toyota Rav4, Honda CR-V, and Mazda CX-5 the only Honda CR-V has CVT - continuously variable transmission?

The potential buyers might be wondering: how reliable is this kind of transmission? There are thousands of questions, answers, and polar opinions in car forums. But let’s be absolutely objective here the statistics of car service calls aren't pretty: Compared with concurrents, Honda owners have problems with CVT two times more often than others in the first three years of use.

Of course, a CVT car is more dynamic and fuel-efficient, but if car reliability is important to you, You'd be better off taking a classic automatic transmission.

most_reliable_honda_models.title: Most reliable Honda cars
most_reliable_honda_models.text:
The Honda Civic, Honda Accord, Honda CR-V, Honda Fit, and Honda HR-V are all popular models of cars produced by Honda, a renowned Japanese automotive manufacturer. Each of these models caters to different market segments and offers various features and specifications.
 The Honda HR-V has the best reliability rating of all the Honda models in this CarDefects dataset. The studies show the severity and frequency of repairs experienced by HR-V owners are much less than others. The HR-V’s average costs are even more impressive than all subcompact SUVs, estimated at $466. And HR-V’s repairs cost less than half the average $652 that all vehicle owners spend annually.
most_reliable_honda_models.cards: [{"title":"Honda Civic","text":"The Honda Civic is a compact car known for its reliability, fuel efficiency, and practicality. It comes in various body styles, including sedan, coupe, and hatchback, making it a versatile choice for a wide range of customers. The Civic is often favored for its comfortable interior, smooth ride, and advanced safety features"},{"title":"honda accord","text":"The Honda Accord is a mid-size sedan (and previously available as a coupe) that offers a comfortable and spacious cabin with a well-balanced combination of performance and fuel efficiency. It is renowned for its strong resale value, dependable reputation, and a range of available features, making it a popular choice among families and commuters"},{"title":"Honda CR-V","text":"The Honda CR-V is a compact crossover SUV, known for its practicality and versatility. It offers ample cargo space, a comfortable ride, and excellent fuel efficiency. The CR-V is a favorite among those seeking a reliable and spacious vehicle for daily commuting or family outings"},{"title":"Honda Fit","text":"The Honda Fit, also known as the Honda Jazz in some markets, is a subcompact hatchback designed to maximize interior space and versatility despite its small size. The Fit's \"Magic Seat\" allows for various configurations to accommodate different cargo and passenger needs, making it a practical choice for city driving and urban lifestyles"},{"title":"Honda HR-V","text":"The Honda HR-V is a subcompact crossover SUV that sits below the CR-V in Honda's lineup. It provides a similar blend of versatility and fuel efficiency in a more compact package. The HR-V is a suitable option for those seeking an SUV-like vehicle with better maneuverability and city-friendly dimensions"}]

reliability_of_toyota_camry_and_honda_ac.title: "Toyota Camry vs. Honda Accord: A Battle of Engine Reliability – Who Prevails?"
reliability_of_toyota_camry_and_honda_ac.text:
"Toyota Camry vs. Honda  A Battle of Engine Reliability – Who Prevails?"


When it comes to investing in a vehicle that promises endurance, efficiency, and excellence, reliability stands as the cornerstone attribute car buyers crave. Enter the Toyota Camry and Honda Accord - two titans of the automotive world renowned for their steadfast engines and unwavering performance. In this detailed exploration, we delve into the heart of these mechanical marvels, comparing their reliability through statistics and innovative technologies.

Understanding Engine  Camry and Accord Uncovered

The engines powering the Toyota Camry and Honda Accord have been celebrated for decades as paragons of automotive reliability. Their ability to reach impressive mileage with minimal defects is not simply a stroke of luck but the result of rigorous engineering, meticulous quality control, and the incorporation of state-of-the-art technology.

Toyota’s Legacy of Longevity

The Toyota Camry boasts an engine built on the principles of quality and durability. One key technology setting the Camry's engine apart is their application of Dual Variable Valve Timing with Intelligence (Dual VVT-i). This system allows for optimal valve timing resulting in better fuel economy and emissions, without sacrificing performance. Alongside this, Toyota employs a direct-injection system that ensures efficient combustion, contributing significantly to the engine's lifespan.

Honda’s High-Tech Horsepower

Meanwhile, the Honda Accord engine makes a bold statement with its Earth Dreams Technology. This suite includes DOHC i-VTEC and direct injection, enhancing performance while simultaneously reducing friction and improving fuel efficiency. Honda's engines are further boasted by their use of lightweight materials and a continuously variable transmission (CVT) that adapts seamlessly to changing driving conditions, mitigating unnecessary wear and prolonging engine life.

Statistics Speak Volumes

When the rubber meets the road, data is king. Reliability comparisons between the Camry and Accord have consistently shown low defect rates for both models. Consumer reports and industry breakdowns highlight these vehicles' higher-than-average longevity, with many owners surpassing the 200,000-mile mark without significant engine issues. These statistics solidify the Camry and Accord as top contenders in the realm of reliability.

Comparison of Cutting-Edge Craftsmanship

Breaking down the mechanical intricacies, both the Camry and Accord employ advanced, lightweight materials and precise engineering to reduce the likelihood of mechanical failure. Toyota's and Honda's commitment to using high-tensile steel and other durable components contributes significantly to the reduction of engine stress and the prevention of typical wear and tear.

Moreover, both models feature engines equipped with chain-driven camshafts, mitigating the need for frequent belt replacements and reducing long-term maintenance costs. The attention to such technical details is a testament to both manufacturers' dedication to engine reliability.

 A Head-to-Head Reliability Showdown

In the final analysis, choosing between the Toyota Camry and Honda Accord may come down to personal preference, as both vehicles offer engines that lead the pack in reliability. The emphasis on technical finesse, married with their impressive track records, make them both wise choices for the discerning driver who values a car that won't let them down.

Now that you're armed with knowledge of what makes these engines tick, and the standout technologies that keep them running smoothly, you’re poised to make an educated decision on your next reliable ride. Trust in the resilience of the Toyota Camry and Honda Accord engines as you seek out a vehicle that combines strength, sophistication, and an unwavering commitment to quality.

audi_a4_last_3_generation.title: Reliability of the Audi A4 over the last 3 generations
audi_a4_last_3_generation.cards: [{"title":"Audi A4 B7"},{"title":"Audi A4 B8"},{"title":"Audi A4 B9"}]
audi_a4_last_3_generation.text:
For the last 3 generations, Audi A4 has become more stylish. But… has it become more reliable?

Well, statistically, the answer is yes: within each generation, the amount of service calls has decreased 3-4 times!

Furthermore, the number of engine crashes in the last generation was reduced by 15 times compared with the previous B8 generation! The new A4 has achieved great results thanks to its engines, which are sourced from the Volkswagen Audi Group.

Almost the same positive results about transmission: In the B8 generation, A4 was equipped with old-school Multitronic CVT, S tronic, and Tiptronic automatics as well as manual transmissions, but the sharper, quicker S-tronic twin-clutch arrangement is now the sole self-shifting option.

how_repair_costs_change_as_subaru_models.title: How Repair Costs Change As Subaru Models Age
how_repair_costs_change_as_subaru_models.text:
Subaru has earned a reputation for reliability, but even their vehicles require repairs as the odometer accumulates miles. Tracking service costs by mileage provides insight into which models remain affordable to maintain.

The Subaru Ascent midsize SUV averages around $350 yearly in repairs during the first 50,000 miles. From 50,000 to 100,000 miles, this rises to $400 annually, and beyond 100,000 miles costs reach about $475.

The B9 Tribeca midsize SUV follows a similar pattern. In the first 50,000 miles, owners report spending roughly $300 per year on unscheduled repairs. From 50,000 to 100,000 miles this increases to $375, and after 100,000 miles jumps to $450. 

Our car service call statistics data show that Ascent had more defects than Tribeca (almost double)

On the other hand, the Baja compact pickup displays a relatively comparable trend. For the first 50,000 miles, drivers pay approximately $250 yearly for repairs. Baja has the lowest number of service calls of the pack within the first 25,000 miles (refer to the car service call statistics data provided below).

This climbs to $325 for 50,000 to 100,000 miles and hits $400 beyond 100,000 miles.

While maintenance costs rise as mileage increases in Subarus, they remain relatively affordable compared to other brands. Baja has the lowest average repair bills across its lifespan. The Ascent is most expensive to maintain long-term compared to the three. But even higher-maintenance Subarus remains cost-effective.

Proper maintenance and repair of small issues early help minimize major repair costs down the road. But Subarus' reputation for reliability and longevity shines through in the data, no matter the mileage.

who_wins_on_reliability_toyota_or_lexus.title: Crunching the Numbers: Who Wins on Reliability - Toyota or Lexus?
who_wins_on_reliability_toyota_or_lexus.text:
We all want our rides to be reliable and affordable to maintain. 

Among the brands with  an unbeatable reputation for reliability are Toyota and Lexus. But just how reliable are these Japanese brands compared to each other? 

Let's crunch the numbers.

Analysis of car service call statistics reveals that Lexus edges out Toyota slightly when it comes to long-term reliability per mile driven. The average Toyota have over 27,000 defects reported by 25,000 miles. Lexus models have far less at around 2000 reported defects within the same mileage. 

From the brand model generation search bar:

Choose Toyota and then click “Search for defects by Toyota” on the far right. A graph will come up with the generated data, pulled from useful resources such as nhtsa.gov. 

 Next, click on the brand model generation search bar and choose Lexus (for the comparison), and then click  “Search for defects by Lexus.” This includes a Lexus bar chart, beside the Toyota in orange. 

You can click “By age” or “Mileage” to get the visual comparison data. 

For our case, we used “Total” defects by “Mileage” to get the below bar chart.




So, what makes Lexus the king of reliability mile after mile? It comes down to higher-grade components, more stringent quality control, and fewer standard features to break. Lexus also offers things like stainless steel exhausts that Toyota doesn't.

Of course, Toyota still tops all non-luxury brands for longevity. But for that extra dose of bulletproof dependability, Lexus takes the crown. Its ultra-durable build and upscale parts ensure it outlasts its parent company by tens of thousands of miles before repairs are needed.

toyota_camry_vs_honda_accord_vs_mazda_6.title: Reliability Comparison of Toyota Camry vs Honda Accord vs Mazda 6 Based on Statistics
toyota_camry_vs_honda_accord_vs_mazda_6.text:
Reliability Comparison of Toyota Camry vs Honda Accord vs Mazda 6 Based on Statistics

When it comes to purchasing a new car, reliability is often one of the top concerns for buyers. After all, no one wants to invest their hard-earned money in a vehicle that will constantly break down or require expensive repairs. In this article, we will compare the reliability of three popular midsize sedans: the Toyota Camry, Honda Accord, and Mazda 6, based on statistics.

Toyota Camry:
The Toyota Camry has long been known for its reliability and durability. According to various reliability studies and consumer reports, the Camry consistently ranks high in terms of reliability. For example, the J.D. Power Vehicle Dependability Study consistently rates the Camry as one of the most reliable vehicles in its class. Additionally, the Camry has received high scores in reliability from organizations such as Consumer Reports. This is largely due to Toyota's reputation for building long-lasting and dependable vehicles, as well as their commitment to quality control and engineering.

Honda Accord:
The Honda Accord is another midsize sedan that has gained a reputation for its reliability. Like the Camry, the Accord consistently ranks high in reliability studies. J.D. Power's Vehicle Dependability Study has consistently given the Accord high marks for reliability, and it has also received positive ratings from Consumer Reports. Honda is known for its strong engineering and attention to detail, which contributes to the Accord's reliability. Additionally, Honda has a history of producing vehicles that are known for their longevity, which further adds to the Accord's reliability.

Mazda 6:
While the Mazda 6 may not have the same longstanding reputation for reliability as the Camry and Accord, it has made significant strides in recent years. According to various reliability studies, the Mazda 6 has shown improvement in terms of reliability and durability. For example, J.D. Power's Vehicle Dependability Study has given the Mazda 6 above-average ratings for reliability. Additionally, Mazda has made efforts to improve the quality and reliability of their vehicles, which has been reflected in their recent models. While it may not have the same track record as the Camry and Accord, the Mazda 6 is still considered a reliable option in its class.

In conclusion, all three midsize sedans - the Toyota Camry, Honda Accord, and Mazda 6 - have proven to be reliable vehicles based on statistics and reliability studies. The Camry and Accord have long-standing reputations for their reliability, while the Mazda 6 has shown improvement in recent years. Ultimately, the choice between these three vehicles will come down to personal preference, budget, and specific needs. However, buyers can rest assured that all three options offer a high level of reliability and durability.

volkswagen_golf_vs_mazda_3.title: Volkswagen Golf vs Mazda 3: A Statistical Showdown of Reliability
volkswagen_golf_vs_mazda_3.text:
Title: "Volkswagen Golf vs Mazda 3: A Statistical Showdown of Reliability"

Are you in the market for a new car and torn between the Volkswagen Golf and the Mazda 3? You're not alone. These two models are among the most popular in the compact car segment, and for good reason. They both offer a blend of performance, comfort, and technology that's hard to beat. But when it comes to reliability, which one comes out on top? Let's dive into the statistics and find out.

Reliability is a crucial factor when buying a car. It's not just about avoiding the inconvenience of breakdowns and repairs. A reliable car can save you a significant amount of money in the long run. But how can you tell if a car is reliable or not? That's where statistics come in. By analyzing data on defects, recalls, and customer complaints, we can get a clear picture of a car's reliability.

The Volkswagen Golf and the Mazda 3 are both renowned for their advanced technologies. The Golf boasts a turbocharged engine, a sophisticated infotainment system, and a suite of driver-assistance features. The Mazda 3, on the other hand, impresses with its Skyactiv technology, which enhances fuel efficiency and performance, and its i-Activsense safety features.

But how do these technologies impact reliability? Let's get into the nitty-gritty. The Golf's turbocharged engine, while delivering impressive performance, has been known to have some issues. These include defects in the turbocharger that can lead to costly repairs. The Mazda 3's Skyactiv technology, on the other hand, has proven to be quite reliable, with few reported issues.

However, it's not all about the engine. The Golf's infotainment system, while feature-rich, has been reported to have some glitches. The Mazda 3's i-Activsense safety features, while providing added peace of mind, have also had some minor issues.

So, which car is more reliable? The statistics tell a compelling story. While both cars have their strengths and weaknesses, the Mazda 3 edges out the Golf in terms of reliability. But don't just take our word for it. We invite you to delve into the statistics chart on our website and see for yourself.

In conclusion, while both the Volkswagen Golf and the Mazda 3 are excellent cars, if reliability is your top priority, the Mazda 3 might be the better choice. But remember, statistics are just one piece of the puzzle. It's also important to consider factors like comfort, performance, and personal preference. Happy car hunting!

Keywords: car, defects, reliability, comparison, statistics.
